title: Central Vestibular Dysfunctionâ€”Type I Chiari Malformation
chief_complaint: I have dizzy spells several times a day, usually after exercising or cleaning the house. My head feels like it is 'swimming' and I can't focus. I also get bad headaches starting at the back of my head when I sneeze or cough, and my vision gets blurry when I turn my head quickly.

problem_summary.course: Symptoms have become more intense and frequent within the last 6 months; dizziness now occurs multiple times daily.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Oscillopsia (blurry vision with head movement), diplopia (double vision), occipital headaches triggered by Valsalva-like maneuvers (sneezing/coughing).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Interfering with quality of life; stopped playing softball due to double vision.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking explanation for increased dizziness and visual problems.

history.present_illness: Patient reports multiple daily episodes of dizziness lasting <30 seconds, triggered by exertion. Describes sensation as 'swimming' rather than spinning vertigo. Denies nausea/vomiting. Reports blurry vision with quick head turns and two episodes of diplopia.
history.otologic_history: Denies hearing loss, tinnitus, or aural fullness.
history.medical_psych_history: History of headaches since high school, recently worsened. Headaches triggered by sneezing/coughing, relief found by lying on stomach with head hanging over the edge. No migraine diagnosis. Appropriate contact lens prescription confirmed by ophthalmology.
history.prior_management: Uses over-the-counter pain medication for headaches.
history.patient_goals: Investigate cause of dizziness and visual disturbances.

tests.name: Dizziness Handicap Inventory (DHI)
tests.key_findings: Score indicates a moderate perceived handicap due to dizziness.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Hearing thresholds within normal limits (250-8000 Hz) bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech recognition thresholds (SRT) consistent with pure-tone average. Word recognition scores (WRS) excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Reflexes present at normal or slightly elevated sensation levels (500-4000 Hz).

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG) - Oculomotor
tests.key_findings: Abnormal. Bilateral horizontal gaze nystagmus (direction-changing). Reduced gain on smooth pursuit and optokinetic testing. Nystagmus intruded on pursuit tracings.

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG) - Caloric
tests.key_findings: Robust and symmetrical caloric responses (no peripheral weakness). Significant failure of fixation suppression noted (central sign).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing sensitivity and middle ear function bilaterally. However, vestibular evaluation reveals significant central vestibular dysfunction. Key findings include direction-changing gaze nystagmus, impaired smooth pursuit and optokinetic gain, and a failure of fixation suppression during caloric testing. These results localize pathology to the central nervous system, specifically the cerebellum, rather than the peripheral vestibular system.
counseling_points: Your hearing test is completely normal, ruling out inner ear hearing problems.
The dizziness and balance tests show signs that the issue is coming from the central connections in the brain (specifically the cerebellum) rather than the inner ear balance organs.
The 'swimming' sensation and blurry vision when moving your head are due to the brain's difficulty coordinating eye movements with head movements.
Based on these results and your specific headache symptoms, a referral for an MRI is necessary to look at the structure of the brain and skull base.
notes_for_actor: You do not have spinning vertigo (room spinning). Describe it as 'swimming', imbalance, or hard to focus.
Emphasize the headaches: they start at the back of the head/neck and happen when you cough or sneeze.
Mention that the only way to stop the headache is lying on your stomach with your head hanging over the edge of the bed.
You are concerned because you had to stop playing softball due to seeing two balls (double vision).
